### Section: 1.1 Background of New Orleans:

New Orleans is a city steeped in history, culture, and natural beauty. Its unique location on the Mississippi River, surrounded by water on three sides, has shaped its history and continues to influence its present and future. In this section, we will explore the background of New Orleans, including its geography, history, and cultural influences.

#### 1.1a The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927

The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 is a pivotal event in the history of New Orleans. It was the greatest flood in modern history on the lower Mississippi River, and it had a profound impact on the city and its surrounding areas.

The flood began in the summer of 1926, when heavy rains fell in eastern Kansas, Oklahoma, and the Ohio Valley. These rains continued into the spring of 1927, causing the White and Little Red rivers to break through the levees in Arkansas. The first levee break along the Mississippi River occurred a few miles south of Elaine, Arkansas, on March 29.

Over the next six weeks, numerous levees broke along the Mississippi River from Illinois to Louisiana, inundating numerous towns in the Mississippi Valley. The break at Mounds Landing near Greenville, Mississippi, was the single greatest crevasse to ever occur along the Mississippi River. It flooded an area of up to 20 miles wide and 100 miles long with up to 30 feet of water. Heavy spring rains caused a second major flood in the same region that June, further exacerbating the already devastating effects of the first flood.

In all, 14 parishes in Louisiana and 21 counties in Mississippi were flooded, which were home to more than 931,000 people. To avoid flooding the city of New Orleans, the governor of Louisiana allowed engineers to create the Poydras cut, which saved the city but led to the flooding of St. Bernard and Plaquemines parishes instead. Millions of acres across seven states were flooded, and evacuees totaled 500,000. Economic losses were estimated at US$1 billion (1927 dollars), which was equivalent to almost one-third of the federal budget at that time.

The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 had a profound impact on the city of New Orleans and its surrounding areas. It highlighted the vulnerability of the city to flooding and the need for better flood control measures. It also brought attention to the racial inequalities in the city, as the majority of the evacuees were African American and many were forced to live in overcrowded and unsanitary conditions in relief camps.

The flood also had a lasting impact on the city's culture and history. It led to the creation of the Bonnet Carre Spillway, which is still used today to control flooding on the Mississippi River. It also brought about changes in the city's architecture, with many buildings being redesigned to better withstand future floods.

In the next section, we will explore the history of New Orleans, from its founding by the French in 1718 to the present day. We will also delve into the cultural influences that have shaped the city, from its Creole heritage to its jazz music and cuisine.

#### 1.1b.1 The New Faubourg Lafitte Project

One of the most significant projects aimed at sustaining New Orleans is the New Faubourg Lafitte project. This project was initiated in response to the devastation caused by Hurricane Katrina in 2005, which resulted in the loss of over 1,800 homes in the Faubourg Lafitte neighborhood. The goal of the project was to rebuild the neighborhood in a way that would not only provide housing for its residents but also address the social, economic, and environmental challenges faced by the community.

The project was guided by a set of principles that aimed to create a sustainable and resilient neighborhood. These principles included:

- Active participation of residents in the planning and development process.
- Provision of community supportive services for all residents.
- Safety and security as a top priority.
- Adherence to sustainable building practices and standards.

The project has been successful in achieving these goals and has set a new standard for sustainable redevelopment in New Orleans. The new Faubourg Lafitte neighborhood is now home to over 1,000 residents, and its design has been recognized for its innovative approach to sustainability.

### Subsection: 1.2a City and Building Design

The design of cities and buildings plays a crucial role in their sustainability and vulnerability. In this section, we will explore the relationship between city and building design and how it impacts the overall resilience of a city.

#### 1.2a.1 City Design

The design of a city is a complex process that involves planning and organizing the physical environment to meet the needs of its inhabitants. It includes the layout of streets, buildings, and public spaces, as well as the integration of infrastructure such as transportation, utilities, and services. The goal of city design is to create a livable, functional, and sustainable environment for its residents.

One of the key considerations in city design is sustainability. Sustainability refers to the ability of a city to meet the needs of its current residents without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. This includes considerations of environmental impact, resource management, and social equity. CityScope has been used to analyze and visualize data related to sustainability, allowing city officials to identify areas for improvement and prioritize efforts accordingly.

#### 1.2a.2 Building Design

Building design is another important aspect of city design. It involves the planning and construction of individual buildings, as well as the overall layout and design of a building. The design of a building can have a significant impact on its sustainability and vulnerability. For example, the design of a building can affect its energy efficiency, resilience to natural disasters, and ability to adapt to changing needs and technologies.

In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, the design of buildings in New Orleans was a major focus of rebuilding efforts. The city had to address the vulnerability of its buildings to future storms and other natural disasters. This included considerations of building materials, construction techniques, and the integration of disaster-resistant features. CityScope has been used to analyze and visualize data related to building design, allowing city officials to identify areas for improvement and prioritize efforts accordingly.

#### 1.2a.3 The Role of City and Building Design in Sustainability and Vulnerability

The design of cities and buildings plays a crucial role in their sustainability and vulnerability. By considering factors such as environmental impact, resource management, and disaster resilience, city and building design can help create a more sustainable and resilient environment for its residents. ### Subsection: 1.2b Review on Sustainability and Vulnerability

In this section, we will review the concept of sustainability and its relationship with vulnerability. We will also discuss the various factors that contribute to a city's vulnerability and how it can be mitigated.

#### 1.2b.1 Sustainability

Sustainability is a crucial aspect of city design and planning. It refers to the ability of a city to meet the needs of its current residents without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. This includes considerations of environmental impact, resource management, and social equity.

The concept of sustainability is closely tied to the idea of resilience. A resilient city is one that is able to withstand and recover from shocks and stresses, whether they be natural disasters, economic downturns, or social disruptions. By promoting sustainability, cities can increase their resilience and ensure a better quality of life for their residents.

#### 1.2b.2 Vulnerability

Vulnerability, on the other hand, refers to a city's susceptibility to harm or damage from external factors. This can include natural disasters, economic downturns, or social disruptions. A vulnerable city is one that is not equipped to handle these challenges and may struggle to recover.

The vulnerability of a city is influenced by a variety of factors, including its physical infrastructure, social and economic systems, and environmental conditions. For example, a city with a weak transportation system may be more vulnerable to a natural disaster that disrupts its ability to move people and goods. Similarly, a city with a high poverty rate may be more vulnerable to economic downturns.

#### 1.2b.3 Mitigating Vulnerability

To mitigate vulnerability, cities must address the underlying factors that contribute to it. This can include investing in resilient infrastructure, promoting social and economic equity, and implementing sustainable practices. By promoting sustainability, cities can also increase their resilience and reduce their vulnerability to external factors.

In the case of New Orleans, the city's vulnerability was highlighted by the devastating effects of Hurricane Katrina in 2005. In response, the city has implemented various measures to mitigate its vulnerability, including strengthening its levee system, improving its emergency response plans, and promoting sustainable building practices.

#### 1.2b.4 The Role of CityScope

CityScope has been a valuable tool in analyzing and visualizing data related to sustainability and vulnerability in New Orleans. By using GIS mapping and data analysis, CityScope has helped identify areas of vulnerability and inform decision-making for mitigating vulnerability. It has also been used to track progress and measure the effectiveness of sustainability efforts in the city.

In conclusion, sustainability and vulnerability are closely intertwined in the context of city design and planning. By promoting sustainability, cities can increase their resilience and reduce their vulnerability to external factors. CityScope has been a valuable tool in addressing these issues and helping New Orleans become a more sustainable and resilient city.

### Subsection: 1.3c Guidelines for Writing Effective Essays

#### 1.3c.1 Understand the Assignment

#### 1.3c.2 Plan Your Essay

Effective writing is not just about putting words on a page. It's about having a clear plan and structure for your essay. Start by brainstorming ideas and organizing them into a logical structure. This could be a simple outline, or it could be a more detailed plan with subheadings and notes. The more detailed your plan, the easier it will be to write your essay.

#### 1.3c.3 Write a Strong Introduction

The introduction is your opportunity to grab the reader's attention and set the stage for your essay. It should provide a clear overview of your topic, state your thesis or main argument, and provide some context to help the reader understand the importance of your topic. Remember, the introduction should be concise and engaging.

#### 1.3c.4 Develop Your Arguments

The body of your essay is where you develop your arguments. This is where you present your evidence, explain your reasoning, and support your thesis. Make sure your arguments are well-organized and clearly linked to your thesis. Use examples, data, and other evidence to support your arguments.

#### 1.3c.5 Write a Strong Conclusion

The conclusion is your opportunity to summarize your main points, restate your thesis, and provide some final thoughts. It should be concise and tie back to your introduction. Remember, the conclusion should not introduce new information, but rather summarize and reinforce what you have already presented.

#### 1.3c.6 Edit and Revise Your Essay

Finally, don't forget to edit and revise your essay. This is a crucial step in the writing process. It allows you to check for spelling and grammar errors, improve the clarity of your writing, and make sure your essay meets all the requirements. New Orleans is a city that is acutely aware of the impact of climate change and natural disasters. The city has implemented various initiatives to address these issues, such as the Greening the City Plan and the Sustainable Development Strategy. Our goal will be to understand these initiatives and explore how they are being implemented. We will also examine the challenges that the city faces in achieving its sustainability goals and propose potential solutions.

#### 1.3d.4 Cultural Preservation

New Orleans is a city steeped in history and culture, with a unique blend of African, French, and American influences. The city has implemented various initiatives to preserve its cultural heritage, such as the Historic Preservation Ordinance and the Cultural Districts Program. Our goal will be to understand these initiatives and explore how they are being implemented. We will also examine the challenges that the city faces in preserving its cultural heritage and propose potential solutions.

#### 1.3d.5 Public Health

New Orleans faces significant public health challenges, particularly in the areas of access to healthcare and health disparities. Our goal will be to understand the current state of public health in New Orleans and explore potential solutions to address these issues.

#### 1.3d.6 Transportation and Infrastructure

New Orleans has a complex transportation system that includes roads, highways, public transit, and waterways. The city also faces challenges such as traffic congestion and infrastructure decay. Our goal will be to understand the current state of transportation and infrastructure in New Orleans and explore potential solutions to address these issues.

#### 1.3d.7 Resilience

New Orleans has a history of resilience, having bounced back from numerous challenges, including Hurricane Katrina. Our goal will be to understand the city's resilience strategies and explore how they are being implemented. We will also examine the challenges that the city faces in achieving its resilience goals and propose potential solutions.

By synthesizing these primary goals, we will be able to provide a comprehensive understanding of urban planning and development in New Orleans. We will also be able to propose practical solutions to address the city's challenges and improve its quality of life.




#### 1.4a City and Building Design: Sustainable New Orleans

New Orleans, like many other cities, faces a unique set of challenges when it comes to urban development. The city's history, geography, and culture all play a role in shaping its development, and these factors must be considered when planning for the future. In this section, we will explore the concept of sustainable urban development in New Orleans, focusing on the role of city and building design in creating a more sustainable future for the city.

#### 1.4a.1 Sustainable Urban Development

Sustainable urban development is a concept that aims to balance the needs of the present and future generations while creating a livable and resilient city. It involves creating a city that is environmentally, socially, and economically sustainable. This means considering the impact of urban development on the environment, the well-being of the community, and the local economy.

In New Orleans, sustainable urban development is particularly important due to the city's vulnerability to natural disasters and climate change. The city has already experienced the devastating effects of Hurricane Katrina, and it is facing increasing threats from rising sea levels and more frequent and severe storms. Therefore, sustainable urban development is not just a desirable goal, but a necessary one for the city's survival.

#### 1.4a.2 City Design and Sustainability

City design plays a crucial role in promoting sustainability. The layout of a city can impact everything from energy consumption to public health. For example, a city with a compact, walkable design can reduce the need for cars and therefore decrease carbon emissions. It can also improve public health by encouraging physical activity and reducing air pollution.

In New Orleans, the city's unique history and culture have shaped its design in significant ways. The city's grid system, for example, is a result of its French and Spanish colonial history. This design has both advantages and disadvantages when it comes to sustainability. On one hand, the grid system can facilitate efficient transportation and waste management. On the other hand, it can also lead to urban sprawl and increased energy consumption.

#### 1.4a.3 Building Design and Sustainability

Building design is another important aspect of sustainable urban development. The design of a building can impact its energy efficiency, water usage, and overall environmental impact. In New Orleans, building design is particularly important due to the city's hot and humid climate. Buildings must be designed to withstand the heat and minimize energy consumption.

One approach to sustainable building design in New Orleans is through the use of Building Information Modeling (BIM). BIM is a process that involves creating a digital representation of a building, including its physical characteristics and systems. This model can then be used to analyze the building's performance and identify areas for improvement. By using BIM, architects and engineers can design more sustainable buildings that meet the specific requirements of the project.

#### 1.4a.4 Sustainable Consulting and Design

Sustainable consulting and design play a crucial role in promoting sustainability in New Orleans. Consultants can provide expertise and guidance on sustainable design and help project teams make informed decisions. They can also assist in identifying sustainable materials and systems that meet the project's specific requirements.

In New Orleans, organizations such as Architects Assist aim to provide equity of access to sustainable and resilient design. By offering affordable and accessible design services, they are helping to promote sustainability in the city.

#### 1.4a.5 Building Placement and Sustainability

Finally, building placement is an often overlooked but crucial aspect of sustainable urban development. The placement of a building can impact its energy consumption, water usage, and overall environmental impact. In New Orleans, building placement is particularly important due to the city's vulnerability to natural disasters.

Ideally, buildings should be placed in a way that minimizes their impact on the environment. This can include avoiding suburban sprawl and promoting compact, walkable communities. It can also involve incorporating green infrastructure, such as green roofs and rain gardens, to mitigate the urban heat island effect and improve water quality.

In conclusion, sustainable urban development is crucial for the future of New Orleans. City and building design play a significant role in promoting sustainability, and sustainable consulting and design are essential for guiding the city towards a more sustainable future. By considering the unique challenges and characteristics of the city, we can create a more resilient and livable New Orleans for generations to come.




#### 1.4b New Orleans and Coastal Louisiana: Sustainability and Vulnerability

New Orleans and coastal Louisiana are facing a unique set of challenges when it comes to sustainability and vulnerability. The region is home to a diverse ecosystem, including wetlands, barrier islands, and coastal marshes, which are all facing significant threats from human activities and natural disasters.

#### 1.4b.1 Sustainability in New Orleans and Coastal Louisiana

The sustainability of New Orleans and coastal Louisiana is closely tied to the health of its ecosystem. The region's wetlands, for example, play a crucial role in protecting the city from hurricanes and storm surges. They act as a natural buffer, absorbing the energy of incoming waves and reducing their impact on the city. However, these wetlands are rapidly disappearing due to human activities such as oil and gas exploration, navigation channel dredging, and land subsidence.

In addition to the threats to the wetlands, coastal Louisiana is also facing threats to its barrier islands and coastal marshes. These ecosystems are also disappearing at an alarming rate, primarily due to sediment starvation. The Mississippi River, which used to deposit sediment along the coast, is now diverted into the Gulf of Mexico, depriving the coast of the sediment it needs to maintain its shape.

#### 1.4b.2 Vulnerability in New Orleans and Coastal Louisiana

The vulnerability of New Orleans and coastal Louisiana is also a significant concern. The region is highly susceptible to natural disasters, such as hurricanes and floods, which can have devastating impacts on the city and its inhabitants. The city's low-lying topography and proximity to the Gulf of Mexico make it particularly vulnerable to storm surges and flooding.

In addition to natural disasters, the region is also facing threats from climate change. Rising sea levels and more frequent and severe storms are expected to exacerbate the vulnerability of New Orleans and coastal Louisiana. The city's aging infrastructure, including its levee system, is also a concern, as it may not be able to withstand the impacts of future disasters.

#### 1.4b.3 Sustainability and Vulnerability in New Orleans and Coastal Louisiana

The sustainability and vulnerability of New Orleans and coastal Louisiana are closely intertwined. The region's vulnerability to natural disasters and climate change is exacerbated by its unsustainable practices, such as oil and gas exploration and navigation channel dredging. These activities not only contribute to the loss of ecosystems, but also increase the region's vulnerability to future disasters.

To address these challenges, the region needs to prioritize sustainable practices that protect its ecosystems and reduce its vulnerability to natural disasters and climate change. This includes restoring wetlands, barrier islands, and coastal marshes, as well as implementing more sustainable land use practices. It also involves investing in infrastructure that can withstand future disasters, such as stronger levees and more resilient buildings.

In conclusion, the sustainability and vulnerability of New Orleans and coastal Louisiana are complex and interconnected issues that require a comprehensive and collaborative approach. By prioritizing sustainable practices and investing in resilient infrastructure, the region can work towards a more sustainable and resilient future.




#### 1.4c Rebuilding in Post-Katrina New Orleans

The aftermath of Hurricane Katrina in 2005 brought about a significant challenge for the city of New Orleans and its surrounding areas. The storm caused catastrophic damage, leaving thousands of residents displaced and many homes and businesses destroyed. The rebuilding process was a complex and multifaceted one, involving not only the physical reconstruction of the city but also the social, economic, and political reconstruction of its communities.

#### 1.4c.1 Physical Rebuilding

The physical rebuilding of New Orleans was a massive undertaking. The city had been severely damaged by the storm, with many homes and businesses destroyed or severely damaged. The rebuilding process involved not only repairing and rebuilding these structures but also addressing the underlying issues that had contributed to the damage, such as the city's vulnerability to flooding and the need for better infrastructure.

One of the key challenges in the physical rebuilding process was the lack of a comprehensive plan for what to do about flooded areas. Thousands of property owners were left to gut and repair their property, some in the lowest lying areas of town. Contractors and workers from out-of-state and other countries came in great numbers doing demolition and reconstruction work, some filling hotels and rental property, others living in trailer and tent cities set up in city parks and parking lots.

#### 1.4c.2 Social and Economic Rebuilding

The social and economic rebuilding of New Orleans was just as complex as the physical rebuilding. The storm had not only destroyed homes and businesses but also disrupted the city's social fabric and economy. Many residents were displaced, and the city's economy was severely impacted.

The rebuilding process involved addressing the needs of the displaced residents, providing them with temporary housing and support services. It also involved helping businesses to reopen and recover, and supporting the local economy. The city also had to address issues of inequality and social exclusion, which had been exacerbated by the storm.

#### 1.4c.3 Political Rebuilding

The political rebuilding of New Orleans was a crucial part of the overall rebuilding process. The city had been severely impacted by the storm, and its political systems and structures had been disrupted. The rebuilding process involved addressing the city's governance structures, policies, and processes to ensure that they were responsive to the needs of the city's residents and communities.

The city had to address issues of corruption and accountability, and ensure that the rebuilding process was transparent and inclusive. It also had to address the challenges of coordinating the efforts of multiple agencies and organizations involved in the rebuilding process.

#### 1.4c.4 Challenges and Opportunities

The rebuilding process in post-Katrina New Orleans was not without its challenges. The city faced significant financial and resource constraints, and the rebuilding process was often slow and complex. However, the rebuilding process also presented opportunities for the city to address long-standing issues and make improvements.

For example, the city had the opportunity to improve its infrastructure, including its flood protection systems and public transportation. It also had the opportunity to address issues of social inequality and exclusion, and to promote social cohesion and community resilience.

#### 1.4c.5 Lessons Learned

The rebuilding process in New Orleans has provided valuable lessons for other cities facing similar challenges. The city's experience has highlighted the importance of having a comprehensive plan for dealing with disasters, and the need for strong leadership and coordination in the rebuilding process. It has also underscored the importance of addressing the social, economic, and political aspects of rebuilding, not just the physical aspects.

In conclusion, the rebuilding process in post-Katrina New Orleans was a complex and multifaceted one, involving physical, social, economic, and political rebuilding. Despite the challenges, the city has made significant progress in its recovery, and its experience provides valuable lessons for other cities facing similar challenges.




#### 1.5a Course Number and Name

The course number for this comprehensive guide to CityScope: New Orleans is 1.5a. This course is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of the city of New Orleans, its history, culture, and urban development. It is a required course for all students enrolled in the CityScope program at MIT.

#### 1.5a.1 Course Objectives

The primary objective of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the city of New Orleans. By the end of this course, students should be able to:

- Understand the history and culture of New Orleans, including its unique blend of African, French, and American influences.
- Analyze the urban development of New Orleans, including its physical, social, and economic aspects.
- Identify and discuss the key challenges and opportunities facing the city of New Orleans.
- Apply urban planning principles and methodologies to analyze and address the issues facing New Orleans.

#### 1.5a.2 Course Structure

The course is divided into several modules, each focusing on a different aspect of the city. The modules are as follows:

1. Introduction to New Orleans: This module provides an overview of the city, its history, and its unique characteristics.
2. Urban Development in New Orleans: This module delves into the physical, social, and economic aspects of the city's development.
3. Challenges and Opportunities in New Orleans: This module examines the key issues facing the city, including social, economic, and environmental challenges.
4. Urban Planning in New Orleans: This module introduces urban planning principles and methodologies and applies them to the city of New Orleans.
5. Future of New Orleans: This module explores potential future developments and challenges for the city.

Each module includes readings, lectures, and assignments designed to help students understand and analyze the city. The course concludes with a final project in which students apply what they have learned to a specific issue or challenge facing the city.

#### 1.5a.3 Course Materials

The required textbook for this course is "Comprehensive Guide to CityScope: New Orleans". Additional readings will be assigned throughout the course. All course materials will be made available online.

#### 1.5a.4 Course Policies

Students are expected to attend all lectures and participate actively in class discussions. Late assignments will be accepted up to 24 hours after the due date with a 10% penalty. Plagiarism will not be tolerated and will be dealt with according to MIT's academic integrity policies.

#### 1.5a.5 Course Evaluation

The course will be evaluated based on the following components:

- Participation in class discussions (20%)
- Assignments (40%)
- Mid-term exam (30%)
- Final project (10%)

#### 2.1c Louisiana Purchase

The Louisiana Purchase of 1803 was a pivotal moment in the history of New Orleans and the United States. It was a landmark event that not only expanded the United States' territory but also solidified its position as a global power. The Louisiana Purchase was a result of complex political and economic factors, and it had a profound impact on the city of New Orleans and its people.

The Louisiana Purchase was a deal between the United States and France, brokered by President Thomas Jefferson. The United States paid France $15 million for the Louisiana Territory, which included the land that is now the states of Louisiana, Missouri, Iowa, Arkansas, Minnesota, and parts of North and South Dakota. This purchase more than doubled the size of the United States and opened up vast new territories for exploration and settlement.

The Louisiana Purchase was a significant event for New Orleans, as it became the gateway to the newly acquired territory. The city's strategic location on the Mississippi River made it a crucial port for the transportation of goods and people to and from the Louisiana Territory. This led to a boom in trade and economic activity, making New Orleans one of the wealthiest cities in the United States.

The Louisiana Purchase also had a profound impact on the city's demographics. The territory included a diverse population of Native Americans, French Creoles, Spanish, and African Americans, all of whom brought their own cultures and traditions to the city. This melting pot of cultures contributed to the unique and vibrant culture of New Orleans, which is still evident today.

However, the Louisiana Purchase also brought about challenges for the city. The influx of new people and the expansion of the territory led to conflicts over land ownership and resources. The United States also had to navigate its relationship with the Native American tribes who inhabited the land, leading to the Indian Removal Act of 1830.

Despite these challenges, the Louisiana Purchase was a pivotal moment in the history of New Orleans and the United States. It solidified the city's importance as a port and trading hub, and its diverse population continues to shape the city's culture and identity. The Louisiana Purchase is a crucial part of the city's historical context and is a topic that is still studied and debated today.





#### 2.2a Causes and Impact of the Flood

The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 was a catastrophic event that had a profound impact on the city of New Orleans and the surrounding areas. The flood was caused by a combination of factors, including heavy rainfall, snowmelt, and the failure of the Mississippi River levee system.

The heavy rainfall and snowmelt in the upper Midwest and Great Lakes regions in the spring of 1927 led to a rapid increase in the water levels of the Mississippi River. This was exacerbated by the failure of the levee system, which was designed to prevent the river from overflowing onto the surrounding land. The levees were not strong enough to withstand the high water levels, and they began to break and fail. This led to a rapid increase in the water levels of the river, causing widespread flooding.

The impact of the flood was devastating. The city of New Orleans was cut off from the rest of the country, as the railroads and highways were flooded. The city's water supply was contaminated, and the sewage system was overwhelmed. Thousands of people were displaced, and many lost their homes and livelihoods. The flood also had a significant impact on the city's economy, as the port of New Orleans was closed for several months, disrupting trade and commerce.

The flood also had a profound impact on the city's demographics. The flood led to a mass migration of African Americans from the flood-affected areas to the cities, including New Orleans. This was known as the Great Migration, and it changed the racial dynamics of the city. The flood also led to the development of the jazz music genre, as many African Americans who were displaced by the flood settled in New Orleans and brought their unique musical styles with them.

The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 was a pivotal moment in the history of New Orleans and the United States. It highlighted the need for better flood control measures and the importance of a strong and resilient infrastructure. The city's response to the flood, including the construction of the Hurricane Protection System, has helped to mitigate the impact of future flood events. However, the city continues to face challenges in terms of flood protection and resilience, and the lessons learned from the 1927 flood are still relevant today.





#### 2.2b Response and Government Policies

The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 was a pivotal moment in the history of New Orleans and the United States. It highlighted the need for better flood control measures and the importance of a strong and resilient infrastructure. In response to this disaster, the government implemented various policies and programs to address the issues that were exposed by the flood.

One of the most significant responses to the flood was the creation of the Mississippi River Commission (MRC) in 1928. The MRC was established to oversee the management and maintenance of the Mississippi River and its levee system. The commission is responsible for ensuring that the river is navigable and that the levees are strong enough to withstand future flood events. The MRC also works closely with local, state, and federal agencies to develop and implement flood control measures.

In addition to the MRC, the government also implemented various policies and programs to address the impact of the flood on the city of New Orleans. The Federal Emergency Relief Administration (FERA) was established to provide financial assistance to the city and its residents. The FERA provided funds for emergency relief, including food, shelter, and medical care, to those affected by the flood.

The government also recognized the need for long-term solutions to prevent future floods. The Flood Control Act of 1928 was passed, which authorized the construction of flood control structures along the Mississippi River, including levees, spillways, and dams. These structures were designed to prevent future flooding and protect the city of New Orleans and other communities along the river.

The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 also highlighted the importance of disaster preparedness and response. In response to the flood, the government established the Office of Emergency Management (OEM) to coordinate disaster preparedness and response efforts. The OEM works closely with local, state, and federal agencies to develop and implement disaster preparedness plans and respond to emergencies.

The flood also led to the development of the National Weather Service (NWS) and the establishment of the Mississippi River Forecast Center. The NWS provides weather forecasts and warnings to help communities prepare for and respond to natural disasters, including floods. The Mississippi River Forecast Center is responsible for monitoring and predicting the water levels of the Mississippi River, providing critical information to help prevent future floods.

In conclusion, the Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 was a pivotal moment in the history of New Orleans and the United States. It exposed the need for better flood control measures, disaster preparedness, and a strong and resilient infrastructure. In response to this disaster, the government implemented various policies and programs to address these issues and prevent future floods. These efforts continue to be crucial in protecting the city of New Orleans and other communities along the Mississippi River from future flood events.





#### 2.2c Long-term Effects on New Orleans

The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 had a profound impact on the city of New Orleans and its surrounding areas. The flood not only caused significant damage and loss of life, but it also brought to light the city's vulnerability to flooding and the need for better flood control measures.

One of the most significant long-term effects of the flood was the development of the New Orleans East community. The flood caused a mass migration of African Americans from the city's downtown area to the east bank of the Mississippi River. This migration was driven by the desire for better living conditions and the opportunity for land ownership. The flood also led to the development of the New Orleans East Hospital, which was built in response to the lack of healthcare facilities in the area.

The flood also had a significant impact on the city's infrastructure. The flood control structures, such as levees and dams, that were built in response to the flood have played a crucial role in preventing future flooding events. However, the flood also exposed the vulnerability of the city's aging infrastructure, leading to the development of more resilient and sustainable infrastructure systems.

The flood also brought attention to the issue of social inequality in New Orleans. The majority of the flood's victims were African Americans, who were disproportionately affected by the flood due to their living conditions and lack of resources. This led to the development of policies and programs aimed at addressing social inequality and promoting equal access to resources and opportunities.

In conclusion, the Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 had a profound impact on the city of New Orleans and its surrounding areas. It brought to light the city's vulnerability to flooding, the need for better infrastructure, and the issue of social inequality. The long-term effects of the flood continue to shape the city's history and development, making it a crucial event to understand in the study of New Orleans.





#### 2.3a Desegregation and School Integration

The Civil Rights Movement in New Orleans was a pivotal moment in the city's history, marked by significant social, political, and legal changes. One of the most significant aspects of this movement was the fight for desegregation and school integration.

Desegregation refers to the process of ending racial segregation in schools, while school integration refers to the process of bringing together students of different races in the same schools. The fight for desegregation and school integration was a crucial part of the Civil Rights Movement, as it aimed to address the systemic racism and discrimination that had been perpetuated through segregated school systems.

The history of desegregation and school integration in New Orleans dates back to the 19th century, when the city's public schools were segregated by race. This segregation was enforced by state laws and policies, which mandated separate schools for African American and white students. This system of segregation was deeply rooted in the city's history, as it reflected the broader societal attitudes and beliefs about race and inequality.

The fight for desegregation and school integration in New Orleans gained significant momentum in the 1950s and 1960s, with the emergence of the Civil Rights Movement. Led by activists such as Thurgood Marshall and the NAACP, African American students and their families fought for their right to attend integrated schools. This fight culminated in the landmark Supreme Court case Brown v. Board of Education in 1954, which declared segregation in public schools unconstitutional.

In New Orleans, the fight for desegregation and school integration was met with significant resistance from white communities and political leaders. The city's school system was one of the last in the United States to be fully desegregated, with many schools remaining segregated well into the 1960s. However, the efforts of civil rights activists and the legal action taken by the NAACP eventually led to the full desegregation of New Orleans' public schools in 1969.

The impact of desegregation and school integration on New Orleans was profound. It not only addressed the issue of racial segregation in schools, but also had a significant impact on the city's social and economic landscape. Integrated schools provided African American students with access to better educational opportunities and resources, leading to improved academic achievement and future prospects. Additionally, desegregation helped to break down racial barriers and promote interracial understanding and cooperation, leading to a more inclusive and equitable society.

In conclusion, the fight for desegregation and school integration was a crucial part of the Civil Rights Movement in New Orleans. It not only addressed the issue of racial segregation in schools, but also had a significant impact on the city's social, political, and economic landscape. The legacy of this fight continues to shape the city's history and its ongoing efforts towards racial equality and justice.





#### 2.3b Protests and Demonstrations

The Civil Rights Movement in New Orleans was marked by a series of protests and demonstrations, which were crucial in bringing attention to the issues of segregation and discrimination in the city. These protests and demonstrations were organized by civil rights activists and community leaders, and were often met with resistance and violence from local authorities.

One of the most significant protests in New Orleans was the 1960 lunch counter sit-in at the Woolworth's department store. This protest, inspired by similar sit-ins in other cities, was organized by students from Dillard University and Southern University. The students sat at the lunch counter, which was segregated and only served white customers, and refused to leave until they were served. The protest lasted for several days and attracted national attention, leading to the desegregation of the lunch counter.

Another important protest in New Orleans was the 1963 Children's Crusade, led by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders. This protest, which involved over 1,000 African American students, was aimed at desegregating the city's public schools. The students marched peacefully through the streets, chanting "We want to go to school!" and "Freedom now!" However, they were met with violence from local police and white counter-protesters. The protest resulted in the arrest of over 100 students, but also brought attention to the issue of school segregation in New Orleans.

In addition to these protests, there were also numerous demonstrations and marches organized by civil rights activists in New Orleans. These included the 1963 March on Washington, where thousands of African Americans from New Orleans joined other civil rights activists from across the country in demanding equal rights and opportunities for all.

The protests and demonstrations of the Civil Rights Movement in New Orleans played a crucial role in bringing about change and addressing the issues of segregation and discrimination in the city. They also served as a powerful symbol of resistance and determination for the African American community, and continue to be remembered and celebrated today.





#### 2.3c Leadership and Impact

The Civil Rights Movement in New Orleans was not only marked by protests and demonstrations, but also by the leadership and impact of civil rights activists and community leaders. These individuals played a crucial role in bringing about change and addressing the issues of segregation and discrimination in the city.

One of the most influential leaders in the Civil Rights Movement in New Orleans was A.P. Tureaud. Tureaud was a prominent attorney and civil rights activist who played a crucial role in desegregating public facilities and schools in New Orleans. He was also a key figure in the legal battle to desegregate the University of Louisiana at New Orleans. Tureaud's leadership and legal expertise were essential in bringing about change and securing equal rights for African Americans in New Orleans.

Another important leader in the Civil Rights Movement was Leona Tate. Tate was one of the "New Orleans Three," a group of African American students who were the first to attend an all-white school in New Orleans. Tate and her fellow students, Gail Etienne and Tessie Prevost, faced significant opposition and violence from white students and community members. However, their courage and determination to attend the school paved the way for future desegregation efforts in New Orleans.

The impact of the Civil Rights Movement in New Orleans was significant and long-lasting. The protests and demonstrations brought attention to the issues of segregation and discrimination in the city, leading to changes in policies and laws. The leadership of civil rights activists and community leaders also played a crucial role in bringing about change and securing equal rights for African Americans in New Orleans.

In conclusion, the Civil Rights Movement in New Orleans was a complex and significant event in the city's history. It was marked by protests and demonstrations, as well as the leadership and impact of civil rights activists and community leaders. The movement brought about significant changes and paved the way for a more equal and just society in New Orleans.

We will also examine the role of various stakeholders, including government agencies, community groups, and private developers, in shaping the city's urban fabric. And we will look at the impact of urban planning and design on the city's social, economic, and environmental well-being.

Whether you are a resident of New Orleans, a visitor to the city, or simply interested in urban planning and design, this chapter will provide you with a comprehensive understanding of the city's urban landscape and the forces that have shaped it. So let's embark on this journey of discovery and learning together.




### Subsection: 3.1a Historic Preservation and Architecture

New Orleans is a city steeped in history and culture, and its architecture reflects this rich heritage. The city's buildings and districts are recognized as historic by the National Park Service, and they maintain a small group of architecturally significant buildings. However, the effects of earthquakes and inundation along the "Riberia da Ribeirinha" have made a historical catalogue of these structures difficult.

#### Principles for the Conservation of Heritage Sites in China

The principles for the conservation of heritage sites in China provide a framework for understanding and interpreting the architectural heritage of New Orleans. These principles emphasize the importance of preserving the authenticity and integrity of heritage sites, while also promoting their sustainable use and management. They also stress the need for community involvement in the conservation process.

#### Commentary

Extended commentary clarifies the way in which these principles should be interpreted and implemented. For example, the principle of preserving the authenticity and integrity of heritage sites can be interpreted as a commitment to maintaining the original architectural features and materials of New Orleans' historic buildings. This can be achieved through careful restoration and renovation, while also ensuring that the buildings continue to function in a sustainable and meaningful way.

The principle of promoting sustainable use and management of heritage sites can be interpreted as a call to balance the needs of the present with the needs of the future. This can be achieved through responsible development and adaptive reuse of historic buildings, while also ensuring that they are resilient to future challenges such as climate change and natural disasters.

The principle of community involvement in the conservation process can be interpreted as a commitment to involving local communities in decision-making processes related to the preservation and development of historic buildings. This can be achieved through community engagement and participation in planning and design processes.

#### Architecture of the United States

The architecture of the United States is shaped by a variety of influences, including the country's history, culture, and natural environment. In New Orleans, these influences are particularly evident in the city's historic buildings and districts.

##### Spanish Influences

The Spanish colonial architecture in the United States was markedly different from the European styles adopted in other parts of America. In New Orleans, the Spanish architecture built in the states of Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, California, Florida, and Georgia was similar to the design adopted in Mexico. According to scholars, the Spaniards built without any consideration to the cost, believing that their tenure in America would be temporary. This belief is reflected in the grandeur and ornamentation of many of New Orleans' historic buildings.

##### French Influences

The French Quarter of New Orleans is a testament to the city's French heritage. The simple French colonial houses in the Mississippi Valley, which were consisted of adjoining rooms that opened upon a "galerie", are a distinct architectural feature of the city. These buildings, along with the city's grand French-style mansions, reflect the city's rich history and cultural diversity.

In conclusion, the architecture of New Orleans is a reflection of the city's complex history and cultural heritage. The principles for the conservation of heritage sites in China provide a framework for understanding and interpreting this architectural heritage. By preserving and promoting the authenticity, integrity, and sustainable use of New Orleans' historic buildings, we can ensure that this architectural heritage continues to enrich the city's urban landscape for generations to come.





### Subsection: 3.1b Urban Renewal and Redevelopment

Urban renewal and redevelopment are critical components of urban planning and design in New Orleans. These processes involve the revitalization of existing urban areas, often with the goal of improving the quality of life for residents and promoting economic growth. Urban renewal and redevelopment can take many forms, from the adaptive reuse of historic buildings to the construction of new developments.

#### Urban Renewal in Different Countries and Regions

Urban renewal is a global phenomenon, with different countries and regions approaching it in their own unique ways. For example, in Buenos Aires, Argentina, the Puerto Madero neighborhood was transformed from an old port and dock into a residential and commercial district. This project involved the construction of more than 50 skyscrapers, making it one of the most expensive and exclusive neighborhoods in the city.

In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, the Porto Maravilha project covers a five million square meter area and aims to revitalize the port area. This project involves the development of public networks for water supply, sanitation, drainage, electricity, gas, and telecom, as well as the construction of roads, sidewalks, bike paths, and public spaces.

Hong Kong, known for its land shortage, has implemented various strategies to increase land supply, including urban renewal. The city's government has recently announced plans to consolidate property interests and expedite urban renewal, with the goal of creating more livable and sustainable communities.

#### Urban Renewal and Historic Preservation

Urban renewal often involves the adaptive reuse of historic buildings, which can contribute to the preservation of a city's architectural heritage. This approach is particularly relevant in New Orleans, where many historic buildings have survived earthquakes and inundation along the "Riberia da Ribeirinha". However, the effects of these events have made it difficult to create a historical catalogue of these structures.

The principles for the conservation of heritage sites in China provide a useful framework for understanding and interpreting the architectural heritage of New Orleans. These principles emphasize the importance of preserving the authenticity and integrity of heritage sites, while also promoting their sustainable use and management. They also stress the need for community involvement in the conservation process.

#### Commentary

The commentary on these principles clarifies how they should be interpreted and implemented. For example, the principle of preserving the authenticity and integrity of heritage sites can be interpreted as a commitment to maintaining the original architectural features and materials of New Orleans' historic buildings. This can be achieved through careful restoration and renovation, while also ensuring that the buildings continue to function in a sustainable and meaningful way.

The principle of promoting sustainable use and management of heritage sites can be interpreted as a call to balance the needs of the present with the needs of the future. This can be achieved through responsible development and adaptive reuse of historic buildings, while also ensuring that they are resilient to future challenges such as climate change and natural disasters.

The principle of community involvement in the conservation process can be interpreted as a commitment to involving local communities in decision-making processes. This can be achieved through public consultations and participatory planning processes, which can help to ensure that urban renewal projects are responsive to the needs and aspirations of local communities.




### Subsection: 3.1c Sustainable Urban Design

Sustainable urban design is a critical aspect of urban planning and design in New Orleans. It involves the creation of urban environments that meet the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. This approach is particularly relevant in New Orleans, given the city's history of environmental challenges, including hurricanes and floods.

#### Sustainable Urban Design Principles

Sustainable urban design is guided by a set of principles that aim to create livable, resilient, and environmentally friendly cities. These principles include:

1. **Efficient Use of Resources**: Sustainable urban design aims to minimize the use of resources, including energy, water, and materials, to reduce the environmental impact of urban development. This can be achieved through strategies such as energy-efficient building design, water conservation, and the use of recycled materials.

2. **Resilience to Environmental Challenges**: Given New Orleans' history of environmental challenges, resilience is a key principle of sustainable urban design in the city. This involves designing urban environments that can withstand and recover from environmental disruptions, such as hurricanes and floods.

3. **Integration of Environmental Considerations**: Sustainable urban design integrates environmental considerations into all aspects of urban planning and design. This includes the incorporation of green spaces, the use of sustainable building materials, and the implementation of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of urban development.

4. **Community Engagement**: Sustainable urban design recognizes the importance of community engagement in creating livable and resilient cities. This involves involving local communities in the planning and design process, to ensure that their needs and concerns are taken into account.

#### Sustainable Urban Design in New Orleans

New Orleans has made significant strides in sustainable urban design in recent years. The city's Greening the Big Easy Plan, for example, sets a goal of reducing the city's carbon footprint by 30% by 2030. This plan includes strategies for sustainable building design, energy efficiency, and the use of renewable energy sources.

The city's Urban Agriculture Plan, meanwhile, aims to increase the amount of locally grown food in New Orleans. This plan includes strategies for creating community gardens, supporting local farmers, and integrating urban agriculture into the city's planning and design.

Finally, the city's Office of Resilience has been established to coordinate efforts to build the city's resilience to environmental challenges. This office is working to implement strategies for flood protection, energy efficiency, and green infrastructure.

In conclusion, sustainable urban design is a critical aspect of urban planning and design in New Orleans. By applying the principles of sustainable urban design, the city can create urban environments that are livable, resilient, and environmentally friendly.




### Subsection: 3.2a French Quarter

The French Quarter, also known as the Vieux Carr, is one of the oldest and most historic neighborhoods in New Orleans. It is a National Historic Landmark District and is home to a variety of architectural styles, including Creole cottages, French colonial buildings, and Greek Revival mansions. The French Quarter is a popular tourist destination, known for its vibrant nightlife, colorful buildings, and rich history.

#### History of the French Quarter

The French Quarter was founded in 1718 by the French explorer Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne de Bienville. It was originally known as the "Quartier des Cafs" due to the numerous coffee plantations in the area. The neighborhood was later renamed the "French Quarter" to distinguish it from the American Quarter, which is now known as the Warehouse District.

During the 18th and 19th centuries, the French Quarter was a bustling center of trade and commerce, with numerous warehouses and markets lining the streets. However, in the early 20th century, many of these buildings were demolished to make way for modern developments. Fortunately, a group of concerned citizens formed the Vieux Carr Commission in 1936 to protect the historic buildings in the French Quarter. This commission has been instrumental in preserving the architectural integrity of the neighborhood.

#### Architecture of the French Quarter

The French Quarter is known for its diverse architectural styles, which reflect the city's history of French, Spanish, and American influences. The oldest buildings in the neighborhood are the French colonial buildings, which were built in the 18th century. These buildings are characterized by their simple, rectangular shapes and steeply pitched roofs.

In the early 19th century, the Greek Revival style became popular in the French Quarter. These buildings are characterized by their columns, pediments, and entablatures, which are inspired by ancient Greek architecture. The Greek Revival style is particularly prevalent in the French Quarter due to the influence of the American traders who settled in the neighborhood.

#### Post-Katrina Changes

In 2005, Hurricane Katrina caused significant damage to the French Quarter, particularly in the Lower Ninth Ward. The storm surge and flooding destroyed many buildings and left others in a state of disrepair. In the aftermath of the storm, the city implemented a comprehensive plan to rebuild and revitalize the neighborhood.

One of the most significant changes in the French Quarter post-Katrina was the implementation of a car-free zone in the neighborhood. In 2020, Mayor LaToya Cantrell proposed ending the use of automobiles in the French Quarter, with the exception of residents and service vehicles. This decision was made to preserve the historic character of the neighborhood and to create a more pedestrian-friendly environment.

#### Major Intersections

The French Quarter is bounded by Canal Street to the north, Esplanade Avenue to the east, North Rampart Street to the south, and the Mississippi River to the west. The neighborhood is home to several major intersections, including the intersection of Canal Street and Bourbon Street, which is a popular meeting point for tourists.

#### Frances Street Squats

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, a group of artists and activists known as the "Frances Street Squatters" occupied several abandoned buildings in the French Quarter. These buildings were located on Frances Street, between Chartres and Decatur Streets. The squatters transformed these buildings into living spaces, art studios, and community centers.

The Frances Street Squats were a part of the larger counterculture movement that was happening in New Orleans at the time. The squatters were known for their radical politics, their commitment to community, and their contributions to the arts. The Frances Street Squats were eventually evicted in the early 1970s, but their legacy continues to be celebrated in the French Quarter.
